abstract: People who run businesses alone — they call themselves solopreneurs — use tools that give them the capabilities, or at least the appearance, of larger concerns.
snippet: People who run businesses alone — they call themselves solopreneurs — use tools that give them the capabilities, or at least the appearance, of larger concerns.

This is now more possible than ever thanks to some tools that so-called solopreneurs and other small businesses have at their disposal, giving them the reach and capabilities of far bigger companies.

abstract: We’d all like to seem so efficient that we must have teams of employees and tons of resources at our disposal. What online tools work for you?
snippet: We’d all like to seem so efficient that we must have teams of employees and tons of resources at our disposal. What online tools work for you?
lead_paragraph: I got a sneak peak at Eilene Zimmerman’s guide to tools that can help a small business seem big, and I have to say it got me thinking. While it doesn’t try to be a comprehensive look at the various software and service options available to small businesses — that would be a never-ending project — it offers some nice, quick illustrations of the fact that no matter what your company or your problem, somebody probably has a high-tech tool to help you deal with it. Sometimes you don’t even know you have a problem until you stumble on the tool that solves it.

headline.main: Tech Tools That Can Help a Small Business Seem Big

abstract: New technologies are most commonly encountered through co-workers or as part of a corporate system, but retiring doesn’t have to mean falling out of touch.
snippet: New technologies are most commonly encountered through co-workers or as part of a corporate system, but retiring doesn’t have to mean falling out of touch.
lead_paragraph: HERE is the problem with typical “elder tech” products: there’s not enough “tech” in a phone that uses an oversize keypad but offers limited features, for one example. Advancing age can rob people of their abilities, and products that help mitigate that are good things indeed. But what if the need for that kind of assistance is still decades away? Today’s baby boomers are just now crossing the retirement line, but that does not render them incapacitated. Far from it. It may, however, render them out of touch.

abstract: Johnson & Johnson said Friday that the president of its DePuy Orthopaedics division, a maker of artificial hips and knees that has struggled with product recalls and lawsuits, is leaving the company.
snippet: Johnson & Johnson said Friday that the president of its DePuy Orthopaedics division, a maker of artificial hips and knees that has struggled with product recalls and lawsuits, is leaving the company.
lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson said Friday that the worldwide president of its DePuy Orthopaedics division, a maker of artificial hips and knees that has struggled with product recalls and lawsuits over faulty implants, is leaving the company. The executive, David Floyd, submitted his resignation last week and will leave at the end of March, a spokeswoman said. He had been president of the unit since 2007. He is leaving to pursue interests outside the company, the spokesman, Lorie Gawreluk, said, declining to be more specific. DePuy recalled the ASR XL Acetabular hip system last August, after researchers found 13 percent of patients needed a repeat operation to fix problems with the implant. The company took a $280 million charge in the fourth quarter to pay for the recall. The company faces more than 500 lawsuits by patients who had the hip implants.

headline.main: Johnson & Johnson Implant Unit Executive Resigns
headline.print_headline: Johnson & Johnson Implant Unit Executive Resigns

abstract: The Marvell Technology Group, a maker of electronic circuits, predicted sales for its current quarter would fell short of estimates, setting off an 11 percent decline in its share price.
snippet: The Marvell Technology Group, a maker of electronic circuits, predicted sales for its current quarter would fell short of estimates, setting off an 11 percent decline in its share price.
lead_paragraph: The Marvell Technology Group, a maker of electronic circuits for the communications industry, predicted sales for its current quarter would fell short of analysts’ estimates, setting off an 11 percent decline in its share price. Revenue for the quarter will be $800 million to $850 million, said Clyde R. Hosein, the company’s chief financial officer, in a conference call Thursday. Analysts had estimated $882.5 million. The company made the forecast after reporting a slight increase in net income and sales in the quarter that ended Jan. 29. Marvell, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., reported its results after the close of market trading Thursday. Its stock fell $2.09, to $16.13 a share.

headline.main: Circuit Maker Marvell Forecasts Disappointing Sales
headline.print_headline: Circuit Maker Marvell Forecasts Disappointing Sales

abstract: In a repeat of last summer’s stand-off, Republicans and Democrats play chicken with a reform almost everyone wants to make.

lead_paragraph: So the House has joined the Senate in voting to repeal the expanded 1099 reporting requirements in the health care overhaul law — but as The Times’s Robert Pear unsurprisingly reports, the two chambers remain far apart on the particulars. For one thing, the Republican-crafted House bill also dismantles a second expanded 1099 reporting requirement directed at landlords that was part of the small-business jobs act. But the crucial difference, as Robert reports, is over how to pay for the repeal. House Republicans used the bill as an opportunity to take a swipe at the health care law, forcing Democrats to choose between protecting small business and defending their signal legislative achievement of recent memory.

headline.main: 1099 Repeal: Now What?

abstract: Prosecutors have called it the biggest insider-trading case in United States history. On Wednesday, a jury in federal district court in Manhattan found Raj Rajaratnam guilty of 14 counts of securities fraud and conspiracy. He had been accused of making $63 million trading on illegal information scoured from a network of sources that spanned Wall Street and corporate America. The trial highlighted an array of aggressive tactics the Justice Department used in its long-running investigation into insider trading, including confidential informants, wiretapped phone conversations and top executives as witnesses.

lead_paragraph: It’s hard not to sympathize with Greece after Moody’s latest downgrade of the country. Like Sisyphus, the government has been pushing a heavy rock uphill. It has gotten somewhere, as Athens asserts. The fiscal deficit is six percentage points of gross domestic product lower than it was. But the debt burden will probably prove too heavy and roll Greece back into crisis. The market views a restructuring as highly likely. But while that would fix Greece’s debt problem, it would not in itself solve the country’s competitiveness and growth challenges.

abstract: In a new book, “Better by Mistake: the Unexpected Benefits of Being Wrong,” the author says perfectionism is good, but only up to a certain point.

lead_paragraph: WE all know that old saw that nothing in life is certain except death and taxes. We should probably add mistakes to that category. More than three years ago, I wrote a column about mistakes and my regret about making an error in an article. I asked why we are taught when young that everyone makes mistakes, but as we grow older, we’re more often punished for making mistakes.

headline.main: It’s Just Fine to Make Mistakes
headline.print_headline: To Err Is Human, and Maybe Psychologically Healthy

abstract: The Tomy Company, the Japanese maker of Transformers and Pokémon toys, agreed to buy the RC2 Corporation for $640 million to add Thomas the Tank Engine products in North America.
snippet: The Tomy Company, the Japanese maker of Transformers and Pokémon toys, agreed to buy the RC2 Corporation for $640 million to add Thomas the Tank Engine products in North America.
lead_paragraph: The Tomy Company, the Japanese maker of Transformers and Pokémon toys, agreed to buy the RC2 Corporation for $640 million to add Thomas the Tank Engine products in North America. The offer is valued at $27.90 a share in cash, 27 percent more than Wednesday’s closing price, the companies said. Tomy, based in Tokyo, is seeking overseas acquisitions to revive growth as falling birth rates in Japan, which contributed to two consecutive annual declines in revenue, crimps demand for new toys. In addition to Thomas, RC2 makes products under the Learning Curve, Johnny Lightning and Ertl brands. “This merger further enables Tomy to move towards our goal of increasing our global profile adding significant additional business in North America and Europe,” Tomy’s president, Kantaro Tomiyama, said in a statement. Shares of RC2, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill., rose $2.80, or 11 percent, to $28.31. Tomy’s stock rose 1 percent in Tokyo trading.

headline.main: Maker of Thomas the Tank Engine Toys to Be Acquired
headline.print_headline: Maker of Thomas the Tank Engine Toys to Be Acquired

abstract: The discount chain 99 Cents Only Stores said Friday it had received a $1.3 billion takeover offer from Leonard Green & Partners and the company’s founding family.
snippet: The discount chain 99 Cents Only Stores said Friday it had received a $1.3 billion takeover offer from Leonard Green & Partners and the company’s founding family.
lead_paragraph: The discount chain 99 Cents Only Stores said Friday it had received a $1.3 billion takeover offer from Leonard Green & Partners and the company’s founding family. The company said Leonard Green and the Schiffer/Gold family bid of $19.09 a share for 99 Cents Only, a 14 percent premium over Thursday’s closing price for 99 Cents. The Schiffer/Gold family owns 33 percent of the company. Its partner, Leonard Green, is a longtime investor in retail companies that has struck deals for Jo-Ann Stores and J. Crew. Shares of 99 Cents, which is based in City of Commerce, Calif., rose $2.90, or 17 percent, to $19.58.

headline.main: Founding Family Bids for 99 Cents Only Stores
headline.print_headline: Founding Family Bids for 99 Cents Only Stores

abstract: Valero Energy agreed on Friday to buy Chevron’s refinery in Pembroke, Wales, for $730 million and other related assets for about $1 billion.
snippet: Valero Energy agreed on Friday to buy Chevron’s refinery in Pembroke, Wales, for $730 million and other related assets for about $1 billion.
lead_paragraph: Valero Energy agreed on Friday to buy Chevron’s refinery in Pembroke, Wales, for $730 million and other related assets for about $1 billion. The transaction is the latest move by a big oil company to refocus on exploration instead of less lucrative refining operations. Chevron has already agreed to sell refining assets in more than 20 countries, and it is looking to sell more operations in the Caribbean and Central America. The deal also gives Valero, a major American oil refiner, its first significant foothold in Europe. The Pembroke refinery has a capacity of 270,000 barrels of oil a day, the vast majority of which is crude. Valero said it expected the purchase to immediately add to its earnings per share.

headline.main: Valero Agrees to Buy an Oil Refinery in Wales
headline.print_headline: Valero Agrees to Buy an Oil Refinery in Wales

lead_paragraph: The Ann Taylor Stores Corporation, the women’s apparel retailer, said on Friday that it earned $8 million in its fourth quarter, propelled by a 10 percent increase in sales, topping analysts’ estimates. The company said the profit amounted to 14 cents a share and came on sales of $515 million. The company earned $41,000, or break-even per share, on sales of $469 million a year earlier. Shares of Ann Taylor, which is based in New York, rose $3.08, or 13 percent, to $27.29. The company also said it would change its name to ANN.

headline.main: AnnTaylor’s Profit Tops Forecasts on Higher Sales

Picasso’s “Gertrude Stein” will be there, with his “Boy Leading a Horse.” So will Matisse’s wildly colorful “Woman With a Hat,” which was derided by critics when revealed in 1905 but was soon purchased by the Steins for what would become their pioneering collection of modern art.

abstract: The company said Richard C. Breeden would leave at the end of the tax season, on April 18, to devote more time to his hedge fund.
snippet: The company said Richard C. Breeden would leave at the end of the tax season, on April 18, to devote more time to his hedge fund.
lead_paragraph: H&R Block, the tax preparation company, said Richard C. Breeden would step down as chairman, more than three years after he took control of the company in a proxy fight. Mr. Breeden, 61, plans to leave on April 18, the company said Thursday in a statement. He intends to devote more time to his hedge fund, Breeden Capital Management, H&R Block said. The company did not name a successor. Mr. Breeden, a former head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was elected chairman Sept. 6, 2007.

snippet: “Come Together: The Business Wisdom of the Beatles” treats the band’s successes and failures as a sort of Rosetta Stone for business types everywhere.
lead_paragraph: THE Beatles were stymied. During a 1968 recording session, they couldn’t find a suitable introduction to “Ob-La-Di, Ob-La-Da,” a song written by Paul McCartney. John Lennon didn’t much like the song, and, after several hours, he stormed out of the studio. When he returned, he strode to the piano and banged out several chords, then added petulantly, “Here’s your intro!”

headline.main: Whisper Words of Business Wisdom

abstract: Many young people have never worn a watch. And while new versions alert them to messages on their smartphones, it’s unknown whether that will give them reason enough to buy one.
snippet: Many young people have never worn a watch. And while new versions alert them to messages on their smartphones, it’s unknown whether that will give them reason enough to buy one.
lead_paragraph: HOW many tiny keypad buttons can fit on one wristwatch? At least 28. That’s the number that Hewlett-Packard packed onto its first watch, the HP-01, in 1977. It was such a strange hybrid of watch and algebraic calculator that calling it a mere watch or a calculator would not do it full justice. So HP called it a “wrist instrument.”

headline.main: The Wristwatch Is Reimagined. Will Young Shoppers Care?
headline.print_headline: The Wristwatch Is Reimagined. Will Young Shoppers Care?

abstract: A new book, “Kingpin,” is an account of how a computer hacker wiped clean his competitors’ databases and took their customers.
snippet: A new book, “Kingpin,” is an account of how a computer hacker wiped clean his competitors’ databases and took their customers.
lead_paragraph: FOR sheer entertainment purposes, one of the best subgenres of business books has been the computer-hacker narrative, the kind of technological detective story found in books like “Takedown,” by Tsutomu Shimomura with John Markoff (1996), and my personal favorite, “The Cuckoo’s Egg,” by Clifford Stoll (1989). When done well, these books do what the best business stories do: take readers into strange new worlds to learn strange new things, and not have it taste like cough syrup.

headline.main: Behind a Coup of Cybercrime

One reason is the increasing number of cellphone calls placed or answered indoors, as people use their cellphones to replace or supplement landlines. abstract: They’re not necessarily the ones with the most followers.

abstract: Lessons from the turnaround guys (who see the same mistakes all too often). Do good times make you stupid?
snippet: Lessons from the turnaround guys (who see the same mistakes all too often). Do good times make you stupid?
lead_paragraph: Most of us have an image of the turnaround guy. For some, the term can conjure up images of an unfeeling taskmaster, exemplified by Albert Dunlap, known as Chainsaw Al, who applied his famously ruthless methods to companies like Scott Paper and Sunbeam in the 1990s. Recently, however, I had the good fortune to meet not one but two men who put to rest my stereotype of the turnaround guy as Rambo in pinstripes.

abstract: The top 1 percent of earners receive about a fifth of all American income; on the other hand, the top 1 percent of Americans by net worth hold about a third of American wealth.
snippet: The top 1 percent of earners receive about a fifth of all American income; on the other hand, the top 1 percent of Americans by net worth hold about a third of American wealth.
lead_paragraph: Typically, comments about rising inequality refer to the stark disparities in incomes of the very highest-paid Americans and everyone. We have observed in several posts, for example, that most of the income gains over the last few decades have gone to the very richest Americans. That means the highest-paid Americans have been claiming a larger and larger share of earnings.

headline.main: Inequality Is Most Extreme in Wealth, Not Income
